name: Gorm
sources: Monaghan, Patricia. The Encyclopedia of Celtic Mythology and Folklore. Checkmark Books, 2008.

attributes.attribute: carved into the side of the gorge of the River Avon
descended from a local divinity made monstrous by the interpretations of Celtic (possibly Viking) religion by Christian priests
vestiges of belief in a figure with this name are also found in Orkney

text: British mythological site Gorm (Gorm the Grim) has a giant's representation named after it carved into the gorge of River Avon. Scholars suggest that Gorm likely originated from a nearby deity who was transformed grotesquely due to the influence of Christian priests on Celtic (and maybe Viking) religion. The carving is believed to portray a cannibal and there are remnants indicating the existence of a character bearing the same name in Orkney.
